executive_summary: Hog and pig farmers have been subject to intense volatility over the past several years as trade disputes and fluctuating commodity prices shook the industry. While the challenges of transporting live swine usually mean the industry has very little international trade, an outbreak of the serious African Swine Fever at the start of the period devastated nearly half of the Chinese hog population and forced them to raise imports. The trade war between the US and China caused the already low levels of US exports to China to drop to nearly zero in 2019, though, and the industry wasn't able to seize this monumental opportunity until it was too late. Still, exports to the country skyrocketed in 2020 and 2021 before dropping back down to pre-period levels, which combined with a post-pandemic spike in the price of red meat in domestic markets to boost revenue a staggering 39.9% in 2021 alone. In spite of this exceptional year, the intense volatility hog and pig farms have faced have tempered growth. Industry-wide revenue has been growing at a CAGR of 2.6% over the past five years and is expected to total $28.6 billion in 2023, when revenue will drop an estimated 6.6%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Returning Exports to China Spiked Revenue
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In 2019 the US and China were in a trade war, driving down the value of hog exports to China. When the trade war was resolved, hog exports to China returned, skyrocketing nearly 6000.0% in 2020 and 167.8% in 2021. This unprecedented demand for both live swine and pork products from overseas drove revenue upwards at a year-over-year increase of 39.9% in 2021. However, it was too late for the industry to fully capitalize on the opportunity and exports to China plummeted 84.9% in 2022 as the nation rebuilt its swine herds and tensions lingered.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Pig Farmers Found Success Despite COVID-19
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Hog farms fared far better through the COVID-19 pandemic than many other industries, though the shutdown of some meat processing plants left smaller farms without a buyer for some time. The industry's position in the supply chain insulated it from major changes to operation, as they continued to sell to processors while processors were forced to shift focus and build new relationships with grocery stores instead of restaurants.

Drought hit much of the nation through the middle of the period, reducing crop yields and forcing hog farms to spend more on feed costs. While the industry was able to pass most of these pressures downstream by raising prices in 2021, a widespread inflationary environment left them unable to do so the following year. Profit compressed as a result, though it remains higher than at the start of the period.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: DECLINING MEAT PRICES WILL LOWER REVENUE
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The price of red meat is forecast to fall over the next five years, generating lower revenue for the pork supply chain. Still, the price of poultry will continue to rise, promoting pork with consumers and slowing the industry's slump. These low prices will boost pork consumption over the next five years despite enduring concerns of pork being unhealthier than poultry or seafood.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: TRADE ACTIVITY RETURNS TO MINIMAL LEVELS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Export volumes have already dropped from previous highs and will remain low over the next five years as countries continue to recover from African Swine Fever outbreaks. Live swine are very challenging to transport, so most trade activity happens after processing and packaging. The challenges faced by countries dealing with the disease will be addressed by other heavily pork-producing nations, like Vietnam or Brazil, that benefit from closer proximity to the demand.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: FARMERS WILL INVEST IN NEW TECHNOLOGY
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Hog farming has continually become more concentrated and has trended towards larger operations that benefit from economies of scale, and farmers with comfortable profit will invest in automated machinery to reduce costs and increase production. Investments into genetic modification and data analytics will also boost efficiency for small and medium piggeries.

industry_definition: Establishments in this industry farm hogs and pigs in operations that include breeding, farrowing, weaning and raising feeder pigs or market-size hogs. The term pig usually refers to the domestic mammal when it is young or small, while hog is the name typically given to domesticated pigs that weigh more than 120.0 pounds. While hog feedlots are included in the industry, the transportation of the livestock is excluded.
key_trends: Organic pig farming is on the rise
Organic farms also need a higher level of certification
Government initiatives help out pig farms. The Livestock Indemnity Program and similar policies help subsidize piggeries when unpredictable challenges arise and threaten the industry.
Feed costs surged in recent years
Most pig farms are in the Plains
Other regions have very few pig farms
Market hogs bring in three-quarters of revenue
Meat processors are the main buyers of hogs

market_segmentation.segment_description: When the total number of hogs in the US is high, there is little demand for pigs for use in breeding and slaughtering volumes climb to alleviate feed

Some pig farms only host swine through a certain phase of their life and will raise piglets up to the age they can be resold to a farm that will then feed them a high-calorie diet to gain weight and increase yield just before slaughter. 42.8% of all hog farms are finish-only operations. When pig farms sustain high mortality among their own herds, they rely on other farms to supplement their losses and maintain production volumes. Growing genetic diversity between populations of swine has increased trade of pigs between farms as breeders seek to create hogs with the least fat content and most resistance to harmful diseases.

Some hog and pig farms sell their products to noncommercial food-service establishments like schools, healthcare facilities or the military, though these sales typically account for less than 0.1% of the industry's revenue.

products_and_services.product_description: Nearly three-quarters of the industry's revenue comes from selling market hogs, which are swine that have reached the end of their life cycle on the farm and are ready for slaughter and sale to processing plants. Hogs are expensive to continually feed, so farms try to sell off hogs when they've reached their prime weight and will be most profitable. This segment is the only product line that supplies consumer demand, so revenue is naturally much higher than sales of feeder or breeder pigs.

Hog farms generate some revenue by selling feeder pigs not yet ready for slaughter, usually to other farms facing mortality in their herds. These swine are more expensive to purchase than to raise on their own, so most farms will choose to breed and raise their own replacement pigs if they're able. Piggeries are forced to rely on feeder pigs when sows have low birthing rates. Still, the growing efficiency of birthing through selective breeding and genetic modification has reduced demand for feeder pigs.
Cull stock animals are selected for various positive (e.g., fast gestation) or negative (e.g., runts) characteristics, then removed from the herd for sale, slaughter or other specific functions.
Breeding stock animals show favorable characteristics that farmers hope to pass on to the future herd population. Pig farms can generate higher returns on some pigs by selling them to other farms.

tier_1_suppliers: Farm, Lawn & Garden Equipment Wholesaling in the US
Livestock Production Support Services in the US
Animal Food Production in the US
Farm Supplies Wholesaling in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Hogs and pigs yield red meat. In the agricultural sector, higher prices for commodities, like red meat, boost farmers' revenue and returns because downstream buyers will usually pay the new price. Higher prices also encourage producers to devote more resources to their farm's production, raising national production. The price of red meat is expected to increase in 2023, presenting a potential opportunity for the industry.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Virtually All Imports Come From Canada
international_trade_points.trade_description: Over the past five years, the US has imported hogs from only two countries, Canada and the Netherlands. Because of the challenges associated with transporting livestock and the nation's ability to meet US health standards, virtually all of the nation's imports come from Canada. Import volumes have increased in the years following the COVID-19 pandemic as Canadian hog farmers have been able to undercut the price of domestic hog farms and have successfully navigated supply chain disruptions.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Imports Are Closely Monitored To Avoid Disease
international_trade_points.trade_description: The US Department of Agriculture (USDA) bans all imports of live swine from countries with reported cases of African Swine Fever, a ban that has been especially important in recent years as the disease culled a staggering half of China's hog herds. Enforced by the USDA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), imported swine and swine products are required to be accompanied by documentation proving they have been inspected and tested to ensure they meet animal US health standards.

international_trade_points.trade_title: The Trade War With China Limited Exports
international_trade_points.trade_description: Exports of live swine to China have been especially volatile but skyrocketed nearly 6000.0% in 2020 and 167.8% in 2021 as the Phase One agreement, which ended the 2019 trade war, was signed and pork producers were able to supplement the loss of nearly half of China's hog population. Export volumes to China dropped 84.9% in 2022 as domestic production in the nation recovered and tensions linger. However, exports bounced back in 2023 as swine fever emerged in China again, once again disrupting hog populations.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Exports To Mexico And Canada Are Stable
international_trade_points.trade_description: Unlike those to China, exports to Mexico and Canada have remained within normal fluctuation levels. Live hogs are very difficult to transport long-distance, making them much more commercially viable in markets on the same continent. The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USCMA), implemented in 2020, eliminated tariffs on live swine traded between the three countries and rolled out protocol to ensure all traded swine met health guidelines and were free of diseases.

business_locations.location_description: Over three-fifths of the industry's establishments are located in the Plains because of its favorable climate and cheap land values.

The Great Lakes and Southeast are the second- and third-most-popular regions, respectively. These regions have the proper climate for raising hogs, but the cost of land is more expensive and farmers will need to pay more for feed transportation costs. The Great Lakes, Southeast and Plains regions host over half of the nation's meat processing facilities, so pig farms need to be in these regions to provide hogs to the industry's largest market.

The Great Lakes and Southeast are the second- and third-most-popular regions, respectively. These regions have the proper climate for raising hogs, but the cost of land is more expensive and farmers will need to pay more for feed transportation costs. The Great Lakes, Southeast and Plains regions host over half of the nation's meat processing facilities, so pig farms need to be in these regions to provide hogs to the industry's largest market.

Pig farms in other areas of the country struggle with expensive land, adverse climate, dense populations, expensive feed transportation costs and distance from key markets, so there are very few piggeries in the West, New England, Mid-Atlantic and Southwest regions.

Pig farms in other areas of the country struggle with expensive land, adverse climate, dense populations, expensive feed transportation costs and distance from key markets, so there are very few piggeries in the West, New England, Mid-Atlantic and Southwest regions.

Pig farms in other areas of the country struggle with expensive land, adverse climate, dense populations, expensive feed transportation costs and distance from key markets, so there are very few piggeries in the West, New England, Mid-Atlantic and Southwest regions.

regulations_points.regulation_description: All specialist pig farmers need to go through the process of obtaining a commercial piggery permit, usually from the state board of health. Pig farms located near residences will likely have a harder time obtaining a permit, as they bring concerns of odor, pests and property value declines.

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)'s regulations, especially in the Clean Water Act, require pig farmers to properly dispose of animal waste to avoid contaminating waterways. The EPA currently requires any pig farm with over 2,500 head to obtain National Discharge Elimination System permits for manure storage, and piggeries without a permit have to prove to the EPA that their farm isn't producing any run-off.

regulations_points.regulation_title: ORGANIC PIG FARMERS NEED TO MEET STANDARDS
regulations_points.regulation_description: Pig farmers claiming to produce organic livestock need to receive higher certification and comply with heightened USDA standards. These farmers may be subject to inspections to ensure pigs labeled as organic have access to outdoor areas, shade, shelter, space for exercise and clean drinking water.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The revenue volatility level is very high.
The capital intensity level is high.

basis_points.basis_description: Pig farmers compete on price. While some pigs are more lean and produce higher quality meat, the relative homogeneity of pork products means piggeries need to offer competitive prices to keep sales high.

Organic pig farming is on the rise. Consumers have voiced concerns about the health content of genetically modified pork and the treatment of animals in the pork supply chain, which has made room for specialty farms to charge more for premium, organic pork.

concentration_points.concentration_description: While barriers to entry are moderate, owner-operator establishments still account for most pig farms as it's fairly inexpensive to join the industry at a limited, non-commercial level.

concentration_points.concentration_title: The Industry is Becoming More Concentrated
concentration_points.concentration_description: The adoption of advanced technology and genetic modification has given larger operations powerful advantages over small competitors, who generally can't afford expensive machinery or cutting-edge biotechnology professionals.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Expensive Feed Has Elevated Purchase Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases, which include the costs of buying pigs from other farms and animal feed, are one of the largest cost segments for the industry. Pig farms can cut costs spent on buying feeder pigs by managing breeding on their own, though this will raise other cost segments. The price of feed surged in 2021 and 2022 as droughts and severe weather caused crop shortages, leading this segment to climb to an estimated 31.4% of revenue.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Farmers Need To Account For Depreciation
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Pig farming has continued to become more reliant on automatic feeding machinery and heavy equipment to control climate and lighting of hog housing, which has translated to a higher level of capital intensity and depreciation. Nonemployer farms that don't make use of this technology will naturally have a much more marginal depreciation cost segment, though the

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry's growing reliance on machinery and technology has made it more important than ever to have a high level of capital to keep operations running smoothly. Feed costs can also spike unexpectedly, resulting in an even higher level of capital intensity.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Unpredictable weather conditions, including natural disasters and droughts, can cause livestock mortality and create revenue volatility for hog farmers. Disease outbreaks, like the African Swine Fever epidemic in China at the start of the period, further increase volatility and have dramatic effects on trade patterns. Subsidies from the Livestock Indemnity Program and other government initiatives help farmers cope with heightened losses, though.

The price of feed is the primary input cost for pig farmers. Inconsistent crop yield resulting from changing weather conditions makes this a very volatile expense. Pig farmers shift these costs downstream by raising prices when input costs are high, boosting revenue. These prices vary widely from year-to-year and are also influenced by demand for pork products and consumer preferences.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Selective breeding and genetic modification are raising total yield and lowering fat content for each hog. Leaner pork sells for higher prices and dodges some of consumers' concerns about red meat being unhealthy, raising revenue and helping secure the industry against drops in demand. Some hog farms are adhering to rigorous standards to raise premium organic pork. Other than these improvements to efficiency and quality, pork products have been relatively similar for centuries.

FAQs.question: Have you explored the possibility of producing organic or pastured pork?
FAQs.answer: Organic pork typically has lower demand than other organic meats consumers view as more healthy. Low-fat pork can help mitigate this competition.

FAQs.question: Does your farm export any of its livestock or face direct competition from imports?
FAQs.answer: Importing live animals is difficult, so import penetration is low in this industry.

FAQs.question: How do your operational strategies address biosecurity, and what impact does this have on overall productivity?
FAQs.answer: Biosecurity is critical in the hog and pig farming industry because of the risk of disease outbreaks, which can significantly impact productivity.

FAQs.question: Could you discuss any recent changes in your farming practices aimed at increasing operational efficiency?
FAQs.answer: Operational efficiency plays a key role in competitiveness and profitability in the hog and pig farming industry, given its influence on cost-effectiveness and productivity. Automated feeders and high-yield diets are crucial to success.

FAQs.question: How do you integrate advanced technologies in your farming operations to enhance productivity?
FAQs.answer: Innovative technologies like automated feeders and cleaning systems can offer substantial enhancements in productivity, efficiency and sustainability in hog and pig farming.

FAQs.question: What impact has digitalization had on your operations?
FAQs.answer: The increasing adoption of digitalization in farming can help farmers monitor their herds' health. This improves animal welfare and leads to more informed decision-making.

FAQs.question: How are you coping with compliance to shifting environmental regulations in hog and pig farming?
FAQs.answer: Environmental regulations influence the resource management and waste disposal strategies of hog and pig farms. The USDA's oversight can significantly impact the industry's operations and, potentially, profitability.

FAQs.question: Do you receive any federal subsidies? How much of your revenue do they comprise?
FAQs.answer: Hog and pig farms receive little federal assistance. Upstream suppliers benefit from price floors and direct funding that buoys them against volatility.

FAQs.question: How do you manage fluctuations in feed prices?
FAQs.answer: Heightened feed prices amid low crop yields dramatically boost the cost of farming hogs. Hog and pig farmers accordingly shift costs downstream through price hikes, but these increases can affect their attractiveness with consumers.

FAQs.question: How much of your production is under contract? What is your customer renewal rate?
FAQs.answer: Many hog farms have contracts with pork production companies. This helps offset some volatility in demand and can make transportation costs more manageable.

FAQs.question: How much of your production is devoted to premium products? Do you spend on marketing to position your products as top-quality?
FAQs.answer: Farmers that produce premium hogs (i.e. heavy weights) secure higher prices in livestock markets.

FAQs.question: Is your company dominant in any particular regional markets? Is there land available for potential expansions?
FAQs.answer: Farms close to pork processors reduce transport costs and livestock transit time, reducing tissue damage and maintaining meat quality.

FAQs.question: Do you have the ability to invest in new technologies like automatic feeders or climate control equipment?
FAQs.answer: Successful farms have access to the most recent technology relating to breeding, feed mixes, climate control and health monitoring.

FAQs.question: How has consumer demand for red meat changed in recent years? How do you compete with other meat and poultry producers?
FAQs.answer: In the agricultural sector, higher prices for commodities, like red meat, boost farmers' revenue and returns because downstream buyers will generally pay the new price.

FAQs.question: Do your suppliers raise prices when feed costs increase?
FAQs.answer: For pig and hog producers, a drop in the price of feed puts downward pressure on meat prices. This decreases returns and drags down revenue.

FAQs.question: How has demand from downstream markets trended in recent years? How do you promote the health benefits of pork?
FAQs.answer: The growing popularity of low-fat diets is negatively affecting this industry because pork is generally considered to be high in fat.
